title: Independence number of generalized Petersen graphs

title_detail.value: Independence number of generalized Petersen graphs

summary:
Determining the size of a maximum independent set of a graph $G$, denoted by
$\alpha(G)$, is an NP-hard problem. Therefore, many attempts are made to find
upper and lower bounds, or exact values of $\alpha (G)$ for special classes of
graphs.
  This paper is aimed toward studying this problem for the class of generalized
Petersen graphs. We find new upper and lower bounds and some exact values for
$\alpha(P(n,k))$. With a computer program we have obtained exact values for
each $n<78$. In \cite{MR2381433} it is conjectured that $\beta(P(n, k)) \leq n
+ \lceil\frac{n}{5}\rceil $, for all $n$ and $k$. We prove this conjecture for
some cases. In particular, we show that if $ n> 3k$, the conjecture is valid.
We checked the conjecture with our table for $n < 78$ and it had no
inconsistency. Finally, we show that for every fix $k$, $\alpha(P(n, k))$ can
be computed using an algorithm with running time O(n).

summary_detail.value:
Determining the size of a maximum independent set of a graph $G$, denoted by
$\alpha(G)$, is an NP-hard problem. Therefore, many attempts are made to find
upper and lower bounds, or exact values of $\alpha (G)$ for special classes of
graphs.
  This paper is aimed toward studying this problem for the class of generalized
Petersen graphs. We find new upper and lower bounds and some exact values for
$\alpha(P(n,k))$. With a computer program we have obtained exact values for
each $n<78$. In \cite{MR2381433} it is conjectured that $\beta(P(n, k)) \leq n
+ \lceil\frac{n}{5}\rceil $, for all $n$ and $k$. We prove this conjecture for
some cases. In particular, we show that if $ n> 3k$, the conjecture is valid.
We checked the conjecture with our table for $n < 78$ and it had no
inconsistency. Finally, we show that for every fix $k$, $\alpha(P(n, k))$ can
be computed using an algorithm with running time O(n).

author: A. Azadi
fulltext:
arXiv:1008.2583v2 [math.CO] 27 Feb 2011

Independence number of generalized
Petersen graphs
Nazli Besharati ∗, J. B. Ebrahimi†, A. Azadi

‡

Abstract
Determining the size of a maximum independent set of a graph G,
denoted by α(G), is an NP-hard problem. Therefore many attempts
are made to find upper and lower bounds, or exact values of α(G)
for special classes of graphs.
This paper is aimed toward studying this problem for the class of
generalized Petersen graphs. We find new upper and lower bounds
and some exact values for α(P (n, k)). With a computer program we
have obtained exact values for each n < 78. In [2] it is conjectured
that the size of the minimum vertex cover, β(P (n, k)), is less than
or equal to n + ⌈ n5 ⌉, for all n and k with n > 2k. We prove this
conjecture for some cases. In particular, we show that if n > 3k,
the conjecture is valid. We checked the conjecture with our table
for n < 78 and it had no inconsistency. Finally, we show that for
every fixed k, α(P (n, k)) can be computed using an algorithm with
running time O(n).

Keywords: Generalized Petersen Graphs, Independent Set, Tree Decomposition

1

Introduction and preliminaries

In a graph G = (V, E), an independent set I(G) is a subset of the vertices
of G such that no two vertices in I(G) are adjacent. The independence
number α(G) is the cardinality of a largest set of independent vertices
and an independent set of size α(G) is called an α-set. The maximum
independent set problem is to find an independent set with the largest
∗ Department of Mathematical Sciences, University of Mazandaran, Babolsar, I. R.
Iran n.besharati@umz.ac.ir, Corresponding author
† Ecole Polytechnique Federale de Lausanne (EPFL), Station 14, CH-1015 Lausanne,
Switzerland javad.ebrahimi@epfl.ch
‡ Department of Mathematical Sciences, Sharif University of Technology, P. O. Box
11155-9415, Tehran, I. R. Iran aazadi@gmail.com

1

 number of vertices in a given graph. It is well-known that this problem is
NP-hard [10]. Therefore, many attempts are made to find upper and lower
bounds, or exact values of α(G) for special classes of graphs. This paper is
aimed toward studying this problem for the generalized Petersen graphs.
For each n and k (n > 2k), a generalized Petersen graph P (n, k),
is defined by vertex set {ui , vi } and edge set {ui ui+1 , ui vi , vi vi+k }; where
i = 1, 2, . . . , n and subscripts are reduced modulo n. An induced subgraph
on v-vertices is called the inner subgraph, and an induced subgraph on uvertices is called the outer cycle.
In addition, we call two vertices ui and vi as twin of each other and the
edge between them as a spoke.
In [8], Coxeter introduced this class of graphs. Later Watkins [14] called
these graphs "generalized Petersen graphs", P (n, k), and conjectured that
they admit a Tait coloring, except P (5, 2). This conjecture later was proved
in [7]. Since 1969 this class of graphs has been studied widely. Recently
vertex domination and minimum vertex cover of P (n, k) have been studied.
For more details see for instance [2], [3], [4] and [11].
A set Q of vertices of a graph G = (V, E) is called a vertex cover of G if
every edge of G has at least one endpoint in Q. A vertex cover of a graph
G with the minimum possible cardinality is called a minimum vertex cover
of G and its size is denoted by β(G). In [2] and [4] β(P (n, k)), has been
studied. Since for every simple graph G, α(G) + β(G) = |V (G)| [15], their
results imply the following results for α(P (n, k)), and n > 2k:

Notice that the problem of finding the size of a maximum independent
set in the graph P (n, k) is trivial for even n and odd k, since P (n, k) is
a bipartite graph. For odd n and k, P (n, k) is not bipartite but we can
remove a set of k + 1 edges from P (n, k) to obtain a bipartite graph. Thus
in this case we have n − (k + 1) ≤ α(P (n, k)) ≤ n. So, for odd k, we have
upper and lower bounds for α(P (n, k)) that are at most k + 1 away from n.
In contrast, for even k, P (n, k) has a lot of odd cycles. In fact, the number
of odd cycles in P (n, k) is at least as large as O(n). This observation shows
that for even k, the graph P (n, k) is far from being a bipartite graph and
as we see in continuation, we need more complicated arguments for finding
lower and upper bounds for α(P (n, k)) compared to the case that k is an
odd number.
This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we provide an upper
bound for α(P (n, k)) for even k > 2. In Section 3, we present some lower
bounds when k is even. In both Section 2 and Section 3 we compare
our bounds with the previously existing bounds. Some exact values for
α(P (n, k)) are given in Section 4 by applying results presented in Sections 2
and Section 3. Finally, in Section 5 we prove Behsaz-Hatami-Mahmoodian's
conjecture for some cases by using known lower bounds. We checked the
conjecture with our Table for n < 78, and it had no inconsistency.

2

Upper bound

In this section we present an upper bound for α(P (n, k)) when k > 2 is even
and we will show that the presented upper bound is equal to α(P (n, k))
in some cases. Our upper bound is better than the upper bound given by
Behsaz et.al. in [2].
For t = 1, 2, . . . , n, we call the set {ut , ut+1 , . . . , ut+2k−1 , vt , vt+1 , . . . , vt+2k−1 }
a 2k-segment and we denote it by It . Let G[It ] be the subgraph of P (n, k)
induced by It .
Let S be the set of all maximum independent sets of P (n, k). For
every S ∈ S we denote by f (S) the number of 2k-segments It for which
|It ∩ S| = 2k (1 ≤ t ≤ n).
3

 Define Smin = {S ∈ S|∀S ′ ∈ S, f (S) ≤ f (S ′ )}. Since S is nonempty, Smin
is also nonempty. Let S0 ∈ Smin .
Proposition 1 For any S ∈ S, S ∈ Smin if and only if f (S) = f (S0 ).
Definition 1 For any S ∈ S, we say It is of Type 1 with respect to S if
|It ∩ S| = 2k, of Type 2 with respect to S if |It ∩ S| = 2k − 1, and of Type
3 with respect to S if |It ∩ S| ≤ 2k − 2.

|It ∩ S| ≤ 2k. So every It is one of the above Types.

To show that G[It ] has a unique α-set, let S be an α-set of (G[It ]). Since
α(G[It ]) = 2k, |S| = 2k and S must contain precisely one vertex from each
edge {ui , vi } where t ≤ i ≤ t + 2k − 1. Notice that the set of u-vertices of
(G[It ]) induces a path of length 2k. Therefore |S ∩{ui | t ≤ i ≤ t+2k−1}| ≤
k. The set of v-vertices of (G[It ]) induces a matching of size k. This means
that |S ∩ {vi | t ≤ i ≤ t + 2k − 1}| ≤ k. These two observations show that

t ≤ i ≤ t + k − 1. Now, consider two cases:
Case 1: vt ∈ S.
In this case, ut and vt+k are forced not to be in S. So ut+k is forced to be in

and vt+k+1 to be in S. Since vt+k+1 is in S, vt+1 ∈

contradiction shows that there is no Type 1 It for which vt ∈ S.
Case 2: ut ∈ S.
In this case, similar to the argument in Case 1, each vertex is either forced
to be in S or it is forced not to be in S. So, there is a unique pattern for
S ∩ It when It ∈ T1 (S). Since the pattern shown in Figure 1 is an instance
of an independent set of size 2k for G[It ], it is the unique pattern for such
an independent set.
Lemma 1 guarantees that there is a unique pattern for It ∩ S, if It is of
Special type 2 with respect to S.

1 segment Ir , a Type 3 segment Ir′ will appear before we see another Type
1 segment. This means that |T1 (S0 )| ≤ |T3 (S0 )| and the theorem follows,
as we argued earlier.

3

Lower bounds

In this section we introduce some lower bounds for α(P (n, k)) where k is
even and k > 2.
Here we explain a construction for an independent set in P (n, k) for even
numbers n and k. It happens that for every even n < 78, our lower bound
is equal to the actual value, using a computer program for finding the
independence number in P (n, k).

From each of 2k-segments 1, 2, . . . , ⌊ 2k ⌋ − 1, we choose 2k − 1 vertices
as shown in Figure 3. We also choose the following vertices from the last
2k-segment and the remaining r-segment:
• r = 1:
{u2 , u4 , . . . , uk−2 , uk } ∪ {uk+3 , uk+5 , . . . , u2k−1 , u2k+1 } ∪ {vk+1 } ∪
{vk+2 , vk+4 , . . . , v2k−2 , v2k }.
• 1<r<k:
{u3 , u5 , . . . , uk−3 , uk−1 } ∪ {uk+2 , uk+4 , . . . , u2k−2 , u2k } ∪
{u2k+3 , u2k+5 , . . . , u2k+r−2 , u2k+r } ∪ {v2 , v4 , . . . , vk−2 , vk } ∪
{vk+1 , vk+3 , . . . , vk+r−2 , vk+r } ∪ {v2k+2 , v2k+4 , . . . , v2k+r−3 , v2k+r−1 }.
• k < r < 2k :
{u3 , u5 , . . . , uk−3 , uk−1 } ∪ {uk+2 , uk+4 , . . . , u2k−2 , u2k } ∪
{u2k+3 , u2k+5 , . . . , u2k+r−2 , u2k+r } ∪ {v2 , v4 , . . . , vk−2 , vk } ∪
{vk+1 , vk+3 , . . . , v2k−3 , v2k−1 } ∪ {v2k+2 , v2k+4 , . . . , v3k−2 , v3k }.
One can easily check that in each case, the given set is an independent set
of size specified in the theorem.
Notice that the upper bound given in Theorem 1 and the lower bound in
Theorem 2, and Theorem 3 are very close to each other for every fixed even
k > 2. More precisely, we have the following corollary:
Corollary 2 If k > 2 is an even number then α(P (n, k)) =

(2k−1)
2k n+O(k).

Notice that our lower bounds are considerably better than the lower
bounds obtained in [2] and [9].

Behsaz-Hatami-Mahmoodian's conjecture

Conjecture ([2]). For all n, k we have β(P (n, k)) ≤ n + ⌈ n5 ⌉.
Notice that, since α(G) + β(G) = |V (G)|, this conjecture is equivalent to
α(P (n, k)) ≥ ⌊ 4n
5 ⌋.
Theorem 4 The above conjecture is valid in the following cases:
a) k = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.
b) n is even and k is odd.

6

Polynomial algorithm for α(P (n, k))

In this section we will prove that the independence number of generalized
Petersen graphs with fixed k can be found in linear time, O(n). This result
is a special case of a deep theorem stating that the problem of finding the
independence number of graphs with bounded treewidth can be solved in
linear time of the number of vertices of the graph.
In the continuation we will show that for every fixed k and any integer
n > 2k the treewidth of P (n, k) is bounded. First, we need to formally
define the concepts of tree decomposition and treewidth of a graph.
Definition 2 Let G = (V, E) be a graph. A tree decomposition of G is
a pair (X, T ), where X = {X1 , X2 , . . . , Xn } is a family of subsets of V ,
and T is a tree whose nodes are the subsets Xj , satisfying the following
properties:
1) The union of all sets Xj equals V .
2) For every edge (v, w) in the graph, there is a subset Xj that contains
both v and w.
3) If Xj is on the path from Xi to Xl in T then Xi ∩ Xl ⊆ Xj . In other
words, for all vertices v ∈ V, all nodes Xi which contain v induce a
connected subtree of T .
The width of (X, T ) is defined to be the size of the largest Xi minus one.
The treewidth, tw(G), of the graph G is defined to be the minimum width
of all its tree decompositions. The treewidth will be taken as a measure of
how much a graph resembles a tree.
Theorem A ([5]). The problem of finding a maximum independent set
of a graph G with bounded treewidth, tw(G) ≤ l can be solved in O(23l n)
by dynamic programming techniques, where n is the number of vertices of
graph.
For more details see for instance [1], [5], [6], and [12].
Theorem 5 For any fixed k, the problem of finding independence number
of the graphs P (n, k) can be solved by an algorithm with running time O(n).

13

 Proof By Theorem A, we only need to show that for a given number k,
the treewidth of P (n, k) is bounded. Consider the following tree decomposition of P (n, k) of width 4k + 3. Without loss of generality we can only
consider the case where n > 2k + 1. Let T be the path of order n − 2k − 1
and define X1 , X2 , . . . , Xn−2k−1 as follows:
X1 = {u1 , v1 , u2 , v2 , . . . , uk+1 , vk+1 , un−k , vn−k , un−k+1 , vn−k+1 , . . . , un , vn },
X2 = (X1 \ {u1 , v1 }) ∪ {uk+2 , vk+2 },
X3 = (X2 \ {un , vn }) ∪ {un−k−1 , vn−k−1 },
X4 = (X3 \ {u2 , v2 }) ∪ {uk+3 , vk+3 },
X5 = (X4 \ {un−1 , vn−1 }) ∪ {un−k−2 , vn−k−2 }, and so on.
Notice that in each step we remove two elements and add two other elements. Therefore |Xi | = 4k + 4 for all i. One can easily see that (X, T ) is a
tree decomposition for P (n, k) where X = {X1 , X2 , . . . , Xn−2k−1 }. Thus,
tw(P (n, k)) ≤ 4k + 3 and by Theorem A, the proof is complete.
